qas.question: During what era did the Appalachian Mountains begin to erode?
What did erosion create in the Cenozoic era?
What defined the folds and faults?
How long did it take to carve canyons?

context: By the end of <b0_0>the Mesozoic era<b0_0/>, the Appalachian Mountains had been eroded to an almost flat plain. It was not until the region was uplifted during the Cenozoic Era that <b1_0>the distinctive topography<b1_0/> of the present formed. <b2_0>Uplift<b2_0/> rejuvenated the streams, which rapidly responded by cutting downward into the ancient bedrock. Some <b3_0>streams<b3_0/> flowed along weak layers that define the folds and faults created many <b4_0>millions of years<b4_0/> earlier. Other streams downcut so rapidly that they cut right across the resistant folded rocks of the mountain core, carving canyons across rock layers and geologic structures.
